contentItems.description: On November 23, as crowds gathered for the annual candlelight vigil in memory of assassinated City Supervisory Harvey Milk and San Francisco Mayor Edward Muscone, San Franciscans are urged to write the name of a loved one lost to AIDS on a poster board and carry it with them as they marched. Many are too scared but others write the names: Mark, Roger, David … Later that night, those few dozen poster boards are plastered on the front of the Old Federal Building and become the inspiration for The AIDS Memorial Quilt.
contentItems.title: Candlelight Vigil for Harvey Milk

contentItems.description: The NAMES Foundation project was established in 1987. Their mission is to preserve, care for, and use the AIDS Memorial Quilt to foster healing, heighten awareness, and inspire action in the struggle against HIV and AIDS.
contentItems.title: The NAMES Foundation Project is Established

contentItems.description:
In August, the first Quilt panel arrives for Rock Hudson. In a matter of days, Rock Hudson’s panel, along with 40 others, are featured in a 40-foot high front window of Neiman Marcus in San Francisco. 

Rock Hudson is remembered with 16 Quilt panels including one on Block #1009, created by Jason Derer, with the help of his Aunt Doris Day.
contentItems.title: Rock Hudson's Panel Displayed in San Francisco

contentItems.description: On October 11, 1987 the Quilt was displayed during the National March on Washington For Lesbian and Gay Rights.  It covered a space larger than a football field and included 1,920 quilt panels.
contentItems.title: First Display of the AIDS Memorial Quilt on the National Mall

contentItems.description:
Cleve Jones and Joseph Durant create the first panels for The AIDS Memorial Quilt. The panels measure 3 feet by six feet, roughly the size of a human grave.

On October 11, the first National Display of The Quilt is presented on the Mall in Washington, D.C. and includes 1,920 panels. 

This display transforms statistics into souls and ignites a national conversation on HIV/AIDS.
contentItems.title: From Statistics to Souls

contentItems.description:
“The Quilt is a masterpiece. It is a rare and intense experience of what it means to be human.” 

— Dame Elizabeth Taylor
contentItems.title: Elizabeth Taylor: Actress and International AIDS Activist

contentItems.description: On June 28, to prepare for the first display of The Quilt, volunteers decide to stitch eight individual panels together to create the first block of The Quilt. Those first 44 Quilt panels are sewn into five blocks, which are hung from the Mayor’s Balcony in San Francisco as part of Gay Pride. The four remaining single panels are also displayed as part of an informational table.
contentItems.title: Panels Sewn into Blocks

contentItems.description:
“We thought we’d close the doors after the first year. I even wrote my name and address on the first two panels I made because I wanted them back.” 

– Gert McMullin
contentItems.title: Gert McMullin: Quilt Production Manager and 25 Year Quilt Veteran

contentItems.description: In June, the first Quilt Workshop opens at 2362 Market Street in San Francisco’s Castro Neighborhood. The panel for Reggie Hightower arrives from Atlanta. This is the first panel for someone outside San Francisco and it is the first indication that this Quilt is destined to be a national memorial.
contentItems.title: Beginning of a National Memorial

contentItems.description: In October, a second national display of The Quilt is presented on the Ellipse in Washington, D.C. 8,288 panels on display.
contentItems.title: Panels on Display in Washington

contentItems.description:
From April to July, seven volunteers load The Quilt, all 3500 panels, into a 30-foot white truck the group names Stella. For the next four months, they zig-zag across the country, displaying The Quilt in communities where volunteers step forward and free venues can be secured. Individuals who follow The Quilt from city to city are nicknamed Thread Heads. The tour raises $500,000 for hundreds of AIDS service organizations. More than 9,000 volunteers across the US help the seven-person traveling crew move and display The Quilt. 

In the summer, Dr. Jonathan Mann, founding director of World Health Organization’s Global Program on AIDS, orchestrates a European tour of The Quilt to unite the world’s response to the pandemic and to establish a worldwide ritual to be called World AIDS Day.
contentItems.title: The Quilt Tours the U.S. and Europe

contentItems.description: In October 1988, at the end of its first tour of major US cities, The Quilt was once again laid out on the National Mall.  By this date, the quilt had grown to 8,288 panels.  Celebrities, politicians, families, lovers, and friends read aloud the names of people represented on quilt panels.  The reading of names is not a tradition at every Quilt display.
contentItems.title: The Quilt Grows

contentItems.description: “Common Threads: Stories From The Quilt” wins the Academy Award as the best feature-length documentary film.
contentItems.title: The Quilt on Film

contentItems.description: A second tour of North America brings The Quilt to 19 additional cities in the U.S. and Canada.
contentItems.title: Second American Tour

contentItems.description: The Quilt now includes panels from every state and 28 countries. At the end of 1989, The Quilt is composed of 10,088 panels.
contentItems.title: An International Memorial

contentItems.description: The AIDS Memorial Quilt is nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize.
contentItems.title: Quilt Nominated for Nobel Peace Prize

contentItems.description: The NAMES Project returns to the nation’s Capital for a third time with the entire AIDS Memorial Quilt, this time in the shadow of the Washington Monument. To reflect the global nature of the AIDS pandemic, this display was titled the “International Display.”.
contentItems.title: Third Laying of the Quilt in Washington

contentItems.description: Designers in the U.S. and England join forces to create a series of quilt panels remembering those lost by the fashion industry.
contentItems.title: The Fashion Industry Remembered in the Quilt

contentItems.description:
President Clinton’s inaugural parade. Over 200 volunteers, including representatives of national AIDS organizations and Leanza Cornett, Miss America 1993, carry Quilt panels down Pennsylvania Avenue.

Forever remembered on The Quilt: Rudolph Nureyev, Michael Bennett, Robert Mapplethorpe, Freddie Mercury, Perry Ellis, Tony Perkins, Liberace, Keith Haring, Howard Ashman, Halston, Michael Foucault…
contentItems.title: The Quilt Featured in Clinton's Inaugural Parade

contentItems.description: NAMES Project begins the National Interfaith Program to bring The Quilt to places of worship and to spiritual communities.
contentItems.title: National Interfaith Program

contentItems.description:
Seven hundred Quilt panels from 35 countries are displayed in San Francisco as part of events commemorating the 50th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations.

In San Francisco, the staff must sew 10,000 new panels into blocks for the upcoming national D.C. display. The staff sews 20 hours a day, doing 10-hour shifts. The volunteers that sew all night are called QUILT ZOMBIES. The staff also recruits volunteers from around the country to teach them how to bundle The Quilt, to edge, and grommet. 

After training in San Francisco, the volunteers return home to set-up sewing circles and The Quilt is literally stitched together in communities from coast to coast.“Toward the front, a woman at a sewing machine finished hemming a panel and folded it, carefully keeping the name face down. ’If I look at the names, I get sentimental,’ she said, ’So I don’t look, I just work.’”
contentItems.title: Sewing the Quilt Together

contentItems.description: NAMES Project launches the National High School Quilt Program, a project that opens the doors to HIV prevention education in the school system.
contentItems.title: National High School Quilt Program

contentItems.description: The last time the Quilt was laid out in its entirety, it covered the National Mall, with 47,000 panels.  Since 1987 more than 14 million people have visited the Quilt at thousands of displays worldwide.
contentItems.title: The Quilt Covers the National Mall

contentItems.description:
In October, the entire Quilt — 40,000 panels — is displayed on the National Mall in Washington, D.C. An estimated 1.2 million people visit. Covering the National Mall from the Washington Monument to the grounds of the U.S. Capital Building, The Quilt occupied an area equal to 24 football fields.

President William J. Clinton attends the national Quilt display on the Mall, along with First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton. He is the first U.S. President to visit a display of The AIDS Memorial Quilt.

“I remember when Hillary and I walked on the Mall to see The Quilt. It was a personally emotional thing, seeing the love and devotion that those sections of The Quilt represented for all those people who died prematurely, and knowing that now, with medicine, they didn’t have to die so fast anymore, if we did the right things. It was a very emotional day.” — President William J. Clinton
contentItems.title: Fourth Laying of the Quilt in Washington D.C.

contentItems.description:
The NAMES Project Foundation moves national headquarters to Atlanta. The cross-country move was made to shore up the Foundation’s finances and to be in a better position to address the changing face of HIV/AIDS.

Civil Rights legend and Congressman John Lewis offers remarks at dedication ceremony.
contentItems.title: New Home for the NAMES Project

contentItems.description: In December, the NAMES Project orchestrates more than 300 World AIDS Day displays of the Quilt and brings more than a million Americans face to face with this American treasure.
contentItems.title: World AIDS Day Displays

contentItems.description: “Call My Name” Panelmaking Program is launched in Atlanta to encourage communities of color to create new panels for loved ones lost to AIDS.
contentItems.title: "Call My Name"

contentItems.description: The Quilt is featured alongside Billy Howard’s photography exhibit, “Epitaphs for the Living” in the Very Special Arts of Georgia Gallery.
contentItems.title: "Epitaphs for the Living"

contentItems.description: June 25, The NAMES Project returns to Washington, D.C. to display the 1000 newest Quilt blocks on The Ellipse
contentItems.title: NAMES Project Returns to Washington, D.C.

contentItems.description:
In October , The AIDS Memorial Quilt is declared an official American Treasure under the Save America’s Treasures Act — recognizing The Quilt as part of America’s priceless historic legacy and one that helps explain America’s past to future generations.

“These treasures mark historic and continuing struggles to define, extend and uphold the nation’s founding ideals of freedom and equality.” 
— Brent D. Glass, former Director, National Museum of American History
contentItems.title: The Quilt Is Declared an American Treasure

contentItems.description: The panel for AIDS Activist Roger Lyon becomes part of an exhibition titled, “Smithsonian Treasures of American History” and is displayed alongside the Greensboro lunch counter where students protested racial segregation.
contentItems.title: Activist Roger Lyon's Panel Featured in an Exhibit

contentItems.description: In June and July , The Quilt is presented with the exhibition, “Beautiful Things: A Showcase of South African Craft” as part of the National Black Arts Festival in Atlanta.
contentItems.title: The Quilt at the National Black Arts Festival

contentItems.description:
The Quilt is featured at the opening ceremonies of the Gay Games in Chicago. 

Founder of the Gay Games, Dr. Tom Waddell, who was an Olympic athlete, is remembered with several panels including one on Block #687.

Through its evolution, The Quilt evolved as a powerful tool for social change. In 1987 when the first panel of The Quilt was constructed, public officials were debating mandatory testing and mandatory quarantines of infected citizens. Homophobic reaction to HIV/AIDS was rampant. First dubbed the “Gay Plague” and the disease of drug addicts, HIV/AIDS was a companion to prejudice and ignorance. The Quilt became a unifying force both for the gay community and for society. Quilt tours became a venue for peaceful demonstration; an opportunity for all people to stand together and honor those lost to AIDS and a means to support the gay community.
contentItems.title: The Quilt and the LGBT Community

contentItems.description: From February to April, Andrea Bowers’ exhibition, “The Weight of Relevance” is on display at Secession in Vienna, Austria. The celebrated artist had previously spent more than a month with The NAMES Project for her Quilt based exhibition.
contentItems.title: Artists Inspired by the Quilt

contentItems.Attribution: Kezia L. Ellison's Service Learning Project
contentItems.description: In December, More than 75 teens create HIV/AIDS awareness panels that are displayed with The Quilt at a World AIDS Day event at The Olivet Boys & Girls Club. Kevin Devera, leader of the club, dedicates a new panel in memory of his brother, Rick.
contentItems.title: The Quilt and Teen AIDS Awareness

contentItems.description:
In March, 100 new Quilt panels are begun in Atlanta in conjunction with the National Week of Prayer for the Healing of AIDS — seven panelmaking workshops are held in seven days. These workshops are a part of the “Call My Name” panelmaking program, that invites communities of color to create new panels to memorialize loved ones lost to AIDS.

As part of this commemoration, Rev. Raphael Warnock, the Senior Pastor of Historic Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta, takes an HIV/AIDS test during the Sunday morning service to encourage members to do the same. 

“We don’t like to talk about these things in church. We’ve got to fight the unholy trinity of silence, shame and stigma.” As Reverend Warnock makes these remarks, he stands in front of four blocks of The Quilt.
contentItems.title: National Week of Prayer for the Healing of AIDS

contentItems.description: In December, MetroHealth System in Cleveland, Ohio presents “Art, Activism & AIDS” — a panel-making program that pairs panelmakers with art students and sewing specialists. Presented with a display of the Quilt.
contentItems.title: Panelmakers Collaborate with Art Students

contentItems.description:
World AIDS Day — Emory University hosts 100 Quilt blocks, making it the largest Quilt display on any 
college campus.
contentItems.title: Campus Display

contentItems.description: In August, the NAMES Project partners with “Dreamgirls” Sheryl Lee Ralph to raise awareness and inspire the creation of new panels for members of the African American community. Ralph co-hosts a “Call My Name” panelmaking workshop on the Spelman College campus in Atlanta.
contentItems.title: Sheryl Lee Ralph Partners with the NAMES Project

contentItems.description: Twenty years ago a man came to the San Francisco workshop to drop off a new Quilt panel. This 3-foot-by-6-foot panel included no name, no photographs, no birth or death dates. Instead, this panel was a call to action, a quiet prayer, a stark reminder of what we are all working to achieve.We asked if we could hold on to this panel and only sewn into The AIDS Memorial Quilt when it was truly, the last one. With each Quilt display, each new panel, each scientific advancement, and each moment of recognition that AIDS is about all of us — we inch closer to realizing that goal.
contentItems.title: The Last One

contentItems.description:
In June and July, the Quilt marks its 25 anniversary on the National Mall by participating in the Smithsonian Institution’s 2012 Folklife Festival. The Festival program, titled “Creativity and Crisis: Unfolding The AIDS Memorial Quilt,” brings more than one million visitors face to face with The Quilt and includes an array of craft demonstrations, dance and musical performances, interactive discussions.

The Quilt is the premiere symbol of the AIDS pandemic and the largest piece of community art in the world – a living memorial to a generation lost to AIDS and our most potent HIV prevention education tool.
contentItems.title: The Quilt at the 2012 Folklife Festival

contentItems.description:
Created by the Public Interactives Research Team at University of Southern
California:  Anne Balsamo (PI), Lauren Fenton, and Rosemary Comella.  In
collaboration with researchers at the University California Berkeley:  Roland
Saekow, Madison Allen.  Interactive Timeline powered by ChronoZoom, developed at the
University of California, Berkeley, Microsoft Research, and Moscow State University,
made possible by the Outercurve Foundation.
contentItems.title: AIDS History Interactive Timeline 1.0 Credits

contentItems.description: There were many unofficial titles or descriptions of the cluster of diseases that were afflicting young gay men.  At one point the medical community considered the name GRID: which stood for Gay-related Immune Deficiency.  Another name was the 4-H syndrome, so named for the four groups of people who were mostly afflicted: homosexuals, hemophiliacs, heroine users, and Haitians.
contentItems.title: A disease not-yet named

contentItems.description:
By 2011, scholars had a better understanding about how the initial chimpanzee virus traveled from Central Africa to the West.  Two books reported on the historical evidence that mapped the virus' migration; both books argue that colonialist practices enabled the spread of the disease.
Here a young man gets vaccinated against leprosy in Nigeria in the 1950s.
contentItems.title: How the initial infection traveled

contentItems.description: Between 1884 and 1924, somewhere near modern-day Kinshasa in West Central Africa, a hunter kills a chimpanzee. Some of the animal's blood enters the hunter's body, possibly through an open wound. The blood carries a virus harmless to the chimp but lethal to humans: HIV. The virus spreads as colonial cities sprout up, but the deaths are blamed on other causes.
contentItems.title: From monkeys to humans

contentItems.description:
In June, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) in the US publishes a report about
five young homosexual men with life-threatening PCP pneumonia.  In July, the CDC
reports that an unusual skin cancer -- Kaposi's sarcoma -- is killing young,
previously healthy men in New York City and California.  These symptoms would later
become recognized as "opportunistic diseases" associated with HIV infection. By
year-end, there is a cumulative total of 270 reported cases of severe immune
deficiency among gay men, and 121 fatalities. The above photograph depicts a man
with Kaposi's Sarcoma, a rare cancer that afflicted many gay men in the early days
of what would become known as AIDS.
contentItems.title: Surprising increase in deaths among young men

contentItems.description:
The CDC calls the new disease:  Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome or AIDS. The CDC
estimates that tens of thousands of people may be affected by the disease.
contentItems.title: "AIDS"

contentItems.description: On December 10, CDC reports a case of AIDS in an infant who received blood transfusions. The following week, the Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR) reports 22 cases of unexplained immunodeficiency and opportunistic infections in infants.
contentItems.title: First Infant Cases Reported

contentItems.description:
Gay Men’s Health Crisis, the first community-based AIDS service provider in the U.S., is founded in New York City.
In January, the first AIDS clinic in the United States is established in San Francisco.
contentItems.title: First Community Care Providers

contentItems.description:
In April , U.S. Representative Henry Waxman convenes the first congressional
hearings on HIV/AIDS. In this photograph, three AIDS activists are sworn in before a
House Governmental Relations subcommittee hearing on Capitol Hill to study
strategies for dealing with the fatal disease.  Left to right: Michael Callen (New
York), Roger Lyon (San Francisco), and Anthony Ferrara (Washington).
contentItems.title: First Congressional hearings

contentItems.description: AIDS is seen in people with hemophilia, convincing scientists that the disease is spread by an infectious agent in contaminated blood.
contentItems.title: First Hemophiliac Cases Reported

contentItems.description: People living with AIDS (PLWAs) take over the plenary stage at the Second National AIDS Forum in Denver, and issue a statement on the right of PLWAs to be at the table when policy is made, to be treated with dignity, and to be called “people with AIDS,” not “AIDS victims.” The statement becomes known as “The Denver Principles,” and it serves as the charter for the founding of the National Association of People with AIDS  (NAPWA).
contentItems.title: Activism for PLWAs' rights

contentItems.description: The heterosexual spread of AIDS in Africa is confirmed.
contentItems.title: Epidemic in Africa

contentItems.description:
In a September  publication, the CDC identifies the major routes of HIV
transmission, and rules out transmission by casual contact, food, water, air, or
environmental surfaces. The CDC offers the initial warning that AIDS may spread by
heterosexual sex and by mother-to-child transmission.
contentItems.title: Transmission Mode Identified

contentItems.description:
Public apprehension spreads based on lack of knowledge and incomplete communication
from government health officials. Rumors circulate of "household spread" -- the
belief that simply sharing living space with someone who is infected with HIV can
lead to infection. In New York, some landlords start to evict PLWAs (people living
with AIDS).
contentItems.title: Fear and Misunderstanding Spread

contentItems.description:
Pasteur Institute researchers Luc Montagnier and Francoise Barre-Sinoussi isolate a
virus from the swollen lymph gland of a person with AIDS. They called it
lymphadenopathy-associated virus or LAV. Independently, Jay Levy, a researcher at
the University of California, San Francisco isolates a virus called AIDS-related
virus or ARV.  It isn't until 1986 that the medical community agrees to call the
virus human immunodeficiency virus or HIV.
contentItems.title: Identification of HIV

contentItems.description:
The American Foundation for AIDS Research (amFAR) is founded to raise funds from
private sources to support medical research on HIV/AIDS.  Elizabeth Taylor becomes
the Foundation's spokeswoman. A scathing government report blasts the United States
Department of Health and Human Services for not providing adequate funds for medical
research on HIV/AIDS.
contentItems.title: Foundation Established to Raise Research Funds

contentItems.description:
In 1985, the First International AIDS Conference is held in Atlanta. By this date,
every region of the world reports at least one HIV case.
contentItems.title: First International AIDS Conference

contentItems.description:
The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) licenses the first commercial blood test,
ELISA, that detect antibodies to HIV.  For the first time, blood banks begin
screening the US blood supply.
contentItems.title: First Commercial Blood Test Available

contentItems.description:
The Secretary of the US Department of Health and Human Services, announces that
Robert Gallo and his colleagues at the National Cancer Institute have isolated the
cause of AIDS:  the retrovirus HTLV-III.   Also announced is the development of a
diagnostic blood test to identify HTLV-III.  Many people express hope that a vaccine
against AIDS will be produced within two years.
contentItems.title: Retrovirus Identified

contentItems.description:
In 1986, as AIDS hysteria builds through the US, Ryan White, an Indiana teenager who
contracted AIDS through contaminated blood products used to treat his hemophilia, is
barred from school.  He sued for the right to return to school; this photograph
shows him after the announcement that he could go back to classes.
contentItems.title: Ryan White Barred From School

contentItems.description:
Rock Hudson is one of the first major Hollywood stars to die of AIDS-related
complications. At first, the popular media reported that he had liver cancer, but he
later admitted that his illness was due to AIDS. This disclosure not only revealed
his homosexuality but had an immediate impact on the visibility of AIDS among the
general US population.  This recognition spurred increases in funding for medical
research related to the disease.
contentItems.title: Rock Hudson Dies of AIDS

contentItems.description:
The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approves the first antiretroviral drug,
zidovudine, commonly referred to as AZT.  The activist group called AIDS Coalition
to Unleash Power (ACT-UP) forms to protest the $10,000 per year cost of the AZT
treatment. It adopts the motto:  SILENCE=DEATH. The US Congress approves $30 million
in emergency funding to states to subsidize the purchase of AZT for people who are
infected with HIV.  This lays the groundwork for what will known as the AIDS Drug
Assistance Program (ADAP) that is authorized by the Ryan White CARE Act in 1990.
contentItems.title: ACT-UP  Protests Cost of AZT

contentItems.description:
Princess Diana makes international headlines by embracing AIDS patients in the UK. 
In response to the outrage, she states:  "HIV does not make people dangerous to
know, so you can shake their hands or give them a hug. Heaven knows they need it.”
In her work with an international AIDS charity, she was one of  first public figures
in Britain to attempt to stop the stigmatization of AIDS patients.
contentItems.title: AIDS as an International Cause

contentItems.description:
After Florida’s Desoto County School Board refuses to allow HIV-positive brothers,
Ricky, Robert, and Randy Ray to attend school, a Federal judge orders the board to
reinstate the three hemophiliacs, who contracted HIV through contaminated blood
products. After the August ruling, outraged town residents refuse to allow their
children to attend school, and someone sets fire to the Ray house on August 28,
destroying it.
contentItems.title: Ray Brothers Ruling

contentItems.description:
For the first time, President Reagan makes a speech about AIDS. Although AIDS was
first identified in 1981, Reagan did not mention it publicly for several years until
a press conference he gave in 1985.
contentItems.title: First Public Acknowledgement by US President

contentItems.description:
The US forbids immigration by people infected with HIV. Under legislation enacted by
the US Congress in 1993, people found importing anti-HIV medication into the country
were arrested and immediately deported back to their country of origin.
contentItems.title: US Immigration Ban

contentItems.description:
American photographer, Robert Mapplethorpe, dies from AIDS at the age of 42. His
work was controversial at the time for its homoerotic content, and consequently
provoked heated debate over the public funding of art. Thi  self-portrait was made
in 1988, a year before his death.
contentItems.title: Photographer Robert Mapplethorpe Dies of AIDS

contentItems.description:
The Joint United Nations Programm on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) reports that the number of
women living with HIV/AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa exceeds that of men.
contentItems.title: Increasing Numbers of Women Infected with HIV

contentItems.description:
The number of reported AIDS cases in the United States reaches 100,000.
ACT UP protests shut down the FDA. Within a week, the FDA begins a "fast-track" policy allowing public access to lifesaving drugs still in clinical trials.
contentItems.title: 100,000 Afflicted

contentItems.description:
Under the direction of the Surgeon General of the US, C. Everette Koop, a pamphlet
titled "Understanding AIDS" was mailed to every household in the US: 107 million
copies. As he wrote in the original report: "We are fighting a disease, not people."
This pamphlet and Koop's prior longer report on HIV infection was an attempt to
shift the US national dialogue about AIDS from a focus on identity (homosexuality)
to a discussion of safer sex practices.
contentItems.title: Message from the US Surgeon General

contentItems.description:
Scientists determine that even before AIDS symptoms develop, HIV replicates wildly
in the blood. The goal of treatment shifts to keeping HIV at low levels.  The term
"T-Cells" enters into popular conversation.
contentItems.title: New Approach to Treatment

contentItems.Attribution: The Single Girl's Guide To Men
contentItems.description:
The first World AIDS Day is held on Dec. 1, 1988.  The event was first conceived in
August 1987 by James W. Bunn and Thomas Netter, two public information officers for
the Global Program on AIDS at the World Health Organization in Geneva, Switzerland. 
Their objective was to use the day to publicize the rate of HIV/AIDS infection
around the globe and to promote educational efforts to stop the spread of HIV.
contentItems.title: First World AIDS Day

contentItems.description: The red ribbon, designed by the New York-based Visual AIDS Artists Caucus, is introduced as an international symbol of AIDS solidarity. According to Frank Moore of Visual AIDS, the color red was chosen for its "connection to blood and the idea of passion - not only anger, but love, like a valentine."
contentItems.title: An International Symbol

contentItems.description:
American basketball star Earvin “Magic” Johnson announces that he is HIV-positive.
The lead singer for the British rock band Queen, Freddy Mercury, dies of AIDS.
contentItems.title: Celebrities with AIDS

contentItems.description: According to the CDC, deaths caused by HIV infection were the third leading cause of death among persons aged 25-44 years. The death rate for HIV infection for men of this age group was seven times that for women.  After 1995, the rates started increasing for women, by 1996, the rate of death in women from HIV became much higher than the death rate for men.
contentItems.title: Leading cause of death for US men 25-44 years old

contentItems.description: The previous year, ACT UP protests at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), demanding the expansion of clinical trials to include more women and people of color.
contentItems.title: Demand for More Representative Clinical Trials

contentItems.description: The CDC launches the first condom ads to air on US television.  The photograph above shows a CDC safe sex campaign poster from 1989.
contentItems.title: Safe Sex Campaign on TV

contentItems.description:
The CDC adds three new conditions—pulmonary tuberculosis, recurrent pneumonia, and
invasive cervical cancer—to the list of clinical indicators of AIDS. The inclusion
of these new conditions mean that more women and injection drug users will be
diagnosed with AIDS.
contentItems.title: Diagnosis Criteria Encompasses Wider Demographic

contentItems.description: The activist group ACT-UP and Benetton put a giant condom on the Place de Concorde in Paris.
contentItems.title: International Awareness Campaign

contentItems.description: Angels in America, Tony Kushner’s play about AIDS, wins the Tony Award for Best Play and the 1993 Pulitzer Prize for Drama.
contentItems.title: AIDS and the Arts

contentItems.description: Pedro Zamora, a young gay man living with HIV, appears on the cast of MTV’s popular show, “The Real World.” One day after the season finale, he dies at the age of 22.
contentItems.title: AIDS on Television

contentItems.description: AIDS is the leading cause of death for all Americans ages 25 to 44. While the demand for treatment has never been higher, medical researchers are unable to develop more effective drugs.  The search for a vaccine continues to elude the efforts of medical researchers.
contentItems.title: Facing AIDS

contentItems.description:
Medical researchers develop a new treatment approach referred to as an AIDS drug
"cocktail".  It consists of a combination of drugs.  Called highly active
anti-retroviral therapy or HAART, the treatment can cut HIV viral load to
undetectable levels.  Hope surges when AIDS researcher David Ho, MD, suggests
treatment could eliminate HIV from the body.  He's wrong -- it's later found that
HIV hides in dormant cells.  In one year, deaths from AIDS in the US decline by more
than 40%.
contentItems.title: HAART

contentItems.description:
UN Secretary General Kofi Annan proposes the Global Fund to Fight HIV/AIDS, TB and
Malaria. The purpose of the Global Fund is to mobilize, manage, and distribute funds
to fight the pandemic of infectious diseases. Treatment is still totally unavailable
to the vast majority of people living with HIV throughout the globe. Only 1% of the
4.1 million sub-Saharan Africans with HIV receive anti-HIV drugs.  The above
photograph show an aerial view of a graveyard in South Africa, where 250,000 died of
AIDS in a single year.
contentItems.title: Developing Nations Demand Access to Treatment

contentItems.description: AIDS becomes the leading cause of death worldwide for people aged 15 to 59.
contentItems.title: Know Your Status

contentItems.description: In 2000, President Clinton issues an Executive Order to assist developing countries in importing and producing generic HIV treatments.
contentItems.title: International Outreach

contentItems.description: In 2003, President Bush announces the $15 billion President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief. The prevention portion of the plan is criticized for over-emphasis on abstinence. But the plan provides much-needed HIV/AIDS-treatment funds to 15 nations.
contentItems.title: PEPFAR

contentItems.description: The 14th International AIDS Conference is held in Barcelona, Spain in 2002. Dozens of countries report they are experiencing serious HIV/AIDS epidemics, and many more are on the brink.
contentItems.title: The Epidemic Becomes a Pandemic

contentItems.description:
After generic drug manufacturers agree to produce discounted, generic forms of
HIV/AIDS drugs for developing countries, several major pharmaceutical manufacturers
also agree reduce drug prices to those countries.  The Joint United Nations Program
on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS), along with the World Health Organization (WHO), and other
global health groups announce a joint initiative with five major pharmaceutical
manufacturers to negotiate reduced prices for HIV/AIDS drugs in developing
countries.
contentItems.title: Generic AIDS Drugs Reach the World Market

contentItems.description:
Awareness grows that HAART has serious side effects. Increasing evidence of drug resistance also calls into question the “hit early, hit hard” strategy.

In the ensuing years, the FDA approves new classes of drugs that make HIV treatment safer, easier, and more effective. But the drugs still do not cure AIDS.
contentItems.title: Beyond HAART

contentItems.description:
UNAIDS calculates that the global spread of AIDS peaked in 1996 at 3.5 million new
infections. Deaths peaked in 2004, at 2.2 million.  But by 2009, the figures are
still grim:  2.7 million new HIV infections and 2 million AIDS deaths in 2008.  Half
of those who need it get no treatment.  Polls show most Americans no longer consider
AIDS a major problem.  They're wrong.   African Americans -- 12% of the U.S.
population -- get 45% of new HIV infections.
contentItems.title: Still an Epidemic, Many Untreated

contentItems.description: Luc Montagnier and Francoise Barre-Sinoussi awarded Nobel Prize in medicine for discovery of HIV.
contentItems.title: Nobel Prize Awarded

contentItems.description:
US President Barack Obama announces that his administration will officially lift the
HIV travel and immigration ban in January 2010. The lifting of the travel ban occurs
in conjunction with the announcement that the International AIDS Conference will
return to the United States in 2012 for the first time in more than 20 years.
contentItems.title: Lift of Immigration Ban

contentItems.description: In 2009, black women accounted for 30% of new HIV infections among all blacks in the US.  Estimated rate of new HIV infections for black women was more than 15 times as high as the rate for white women, and more that three times as high as that of Latina women.
contentItems.title: African-American Women at Highest Risk

contentItems.description: Of the 33 million people now living with HIV, 3 million are getting treatment. That's less than a third of those who need immediate treatment. Yet for the first time, global AIDS deaths decline.
contentItems.title: Global AIDS Deaths Decline

contentItems.description: Health officials report that Washington, DC has a higher rate of HIV (3% prevalence) than West Africa – enough to describe it as a “severe and generalized epidemic.” The White House and the CDC launch the Act Against AIDS campaign, a communication campaign designed to reduce HIV incidence in the United States. The CDC also launches the Act Against AIDS Leadership Initiative (AAALI), to harness the collective strength and reach of traditional, longstanding African American institutions to increase awareness, knowledge, and action within Black communities across the U.S.
contentItems.title: Addressing Communities

contentItems.description: Medical researchers have identified more than a dozen antibodies that target the HIV virus.  This provides hope that they can create a vaccine that offers long-term protection against AIDS. One antibody in particular, PGT 128, is considered among the most potent and promising.  In laboratory tests, it is shown to prevent 70% of viruses from infecting cells. This HIV-neutralizing antibody may lead to new vaccines.
contentItems.title: Hope for a Vaccine

contentItems.description:
In June 2011 3,000 people participate in the United Nation’s (UN) High-Level Meeting
on HIV/AIDS in New York. The session recognizes critical milestones, including three
decades of the pandemic and the 10-year anniversary of the 2001 UN General Assembly
Special Session on HIV/AIDS and the resulting Declaration of Commitment. At the
Meeting, the U.S. joined with other partners in launching a global plan to eliminate
mother-to-child transmission of HIV and keep mothers alive.
contentItems.title: Global Plan to End Mother-to-Child Transmission

contentItems.description:
On September 30, the first Road to AIDS 2012 Town Hall meeting kicks off in San
Francisco. This is the first of 15 meetings to be held across the country, leading
up to the XIX International AIDS Conference (AIDS 2012), to be held July 22-27,
2012, in Washington, DC.
contentItems.title: Road to AIDS 2012

contentItems.description:
Created by the Public Interactives Research Team at University of Southern
California:  Anne Balsamo (PI), Lauren Fenton, and Rosemary Comella.  In
collaboration with researchers at the University California Berkeley:  Roland
Saekow, Madison Allen.  Interactive Timeline powered by ChronoZoom, developed at the
University of California, Berkeley, Microsoft Research, and Moscow State University,
made possible by the Outercurve Foundation.
contentItems.title: AIDS History Interactive Timeline 1.0 Credits
